sen.j: 丁子屋（ちょうじや）は、江戸時代にはすでに存在が確認されている、日本の古くからの屋号（商号）のひとつ。
sen.e: Choji-ya (丁子屋) is one of the oldest yago (trade name), which is confirmed its existence in the Edo period.
Choji-ya (丁子屋) is one of the oldest yago (trade name), which is confirmed to have already existed in the Edo period.

sen.j: 丁子に由来する商号で、丁子の絵柄が含まれる家紋を持つ商家が名乗った。
sen.e: The yago is a trade name derived from choji (a clove tree), and it was used by shoka (mercantile house) whose kamon (family crest) contained a design of cloves).

sen.j: また、丁子に関する商売を行う者が屋号として使うケースもあった（丁子油・香料・漢方薬など）。
sen.e: Additionally, there were cases that merchants whose business were related to choji (clove oil, perfume, herbal medicines, and so on) used the yago.

sen.e: The usage of the yago of choji-ya had also spread to trades related to plants (indigo-dyeing shops).

sen.e: Including clove oil which is used to take care of a Japanese sword and so on, perfumes and herbal medicines and so on were also none too inexpensive during the Edo period.

sen.j: 丁子屋を名乗る店は数多く存在したが、そういった事情である程度以上の商業資本家としての商家だったものも多い。
sen.e: As a result, although there were a lot of shoke under the name of choji-ya, many of them had a certain level of business capital.

sen.e: Accordingly, there are still such shops which are keeping their noren (a short, split curtain hung at the entrance of a room) from all over the place even after Meiji Restoration.
